content.question: A sphere is connected to a string with negligible mass, as shown, and set into simple harmonic motion by displacing it by a small angle and releasing it from rest. When the sphere is released, it is a height of <math alttext="2 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> above its lowest position (where the gravitational potential energy of the sphere-Earth system is defined to be zero). Shortly after release, the kinetic energy of the sphere is equal to the gravitational potential energy of the sphere-Earth system. At this instant, the speed of the sphere will be most nearly

<math alttext="0.20 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.20</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math>
